Execution Module

The execution module handles order execution, position sizing, commission, and slippage models.

class ml4t.backtest.execution.broker.SimulationBroker(initial_cash: float = 100000.0, asset_registry: AssetRegistry | None = None, commission_model: CommissionModel | None = None, slippage_model: SlippageModel | None = None, market_impact_model: MarketImpactModel | None = None, liquidity_model: LiquidityModel | None = None, fill_model: Any | None = None, enable_margin: bool = True, execution_delay: bool = True, max_leverage: float = 1.0, allow_immediate_reentry: bool = True)[source]

Bases: Broker

Simulated broker for backtesting.

Handles order execution with configurable realism models. Supports multiple asset classes including equities, futures, options, FX, and crypto.

Features: - Execution delay: Prevents lookahead bias by delaying order fills by one market event - Multiple order types: Market, Limit, Stop, Trailing Stop, Bracket - Realistic fills: Slippage, commission, and market impact models - Position tracking: Multi-asset position management - Margin support: For derivatives trading

Parameters:

  • initial_cash (float, default: 100000.0)

  • asset_registry (AssetRegistry | None, default: None)

  • commission_model (CommissionModel | None, default: None)

  • slippage_model (SlippageModel | None, default: None)

  • market_impact_model (MarketImpactModel | None, default: None)

  • liquidity_model (LiquidityModel | None, default: None)

  • fill_model (Any | None, default: None)

  • enable_margin (bool, default: True)

  • execution_delay (bool, default: True)

  • max_leverage (float, default: 1.0)

  • allow_immediate_reentry (bool, default: True)

__init__(initial_cash: float = 100000.0, asset_registry: AssetRegistry | None = None, commission_model: CommissionModel | None = None, slippage_model: SlippageModel | None = None, market_impact_model: MarketImpactModel | None = None, liquidity_model: LiquidityModel | None = None, fill_model: Any | None = None, enable_margin: bool = True, execution_delay: bool = True, max_leverage: float = 1.0, allow_immediate_reentry: bool = True)[source]

Initialize simulation broker with specialized components.

Parameters:

  • initial_cash (float, default: 100000.0) Starting cash balance

  • asset_registry (AssetRegistry | None, default: None) Registry of asset specifications

  • commission_model (CommissionModel | None, default: None) Model for calculating commissions

  • slippage_model (SlippageModel | None, default: None) Model for calculating slippage

  • market_impact_model (MarketImpactModel | None, default: None) Model for calculating market impact

  • liquidity_model (LiquidityModel | None, default: None) Model for liquidity constraints and volume limits

  • fill_model (Any | None, default: None) Model for determining fills

  • enable_margin (bool, default: True) Whether to enable margin trading for derivatives

  • execution_delay (bool, default: True) Whether to delay order execution by one market event (default True to prevent lookahead bias)

  • max_leverage (float, default: 1.0) Maximum leverage allowed (default 1.0 = no leverage). Prevents unlimited leverage as capital depletes. Example: max_leverage=2.0 allows positions up to 2x cash balance.

  • allow_immediate_reentry (bool, default: True) Whether to allow re-entering a position on the same bar where it was exited. True (default) = realistic behavior, allows intrabar exit+entry if liquidity exists. False = VectorBT-compatible mode, prevents same-bar re-entry for validation purposes.

property cash: float

Get current cash balance from Portfolio.

property trades: pl.DataFrame

Get completed trades as a Polars DataFrame.

Returns DataFrame with columns: - trade_id: Unique trade identifier - asset_id: Asset symbol - entry_dt: Entry timestamp - entry_price: Entry execution price - entry_quantity: Position size - entry_commission: Entry fees - entry_slippage: Entry slippage cost - entry_order_id: Entry order ID - exit_dt: Exit timestamp - exit_price: Exit execution price - exit_quantity: Exit position size - exit_commission: Exit fees - exit_slippage: Exit slippage cost - exit_order_id: Exit order ID - pnl: Net profit/loss - return_pct: Return percentage - duration_bars: Trade duration in bars - direction: long or short

Example

>>> broker = SimulationBroker(initial_cash=100000)
>>> # ... run backtest ...
>>> trades_df = broker.trades
>>> print(f"Total trades: {len(trades_df)}")
>>> print(f"Total PnL: ${trades_df['pnl'].sum():.2f}")
can_enter_position(asset_id: AssetId, current_time: datetime) → bool[source]

Check if a new position can be entered for the given asset.

When allow_immediate_reentry=False, prevents entering a position on the same bar where the previous position was exited (VectorBT-compatible behavior).

Parameters:

  • asset_id (NewType(AssetId, str)) Asset to check

  • current_time (datetime) Current bar timestamp

Return type:

bool

Returns:

True if entry is allowed, False otherwise

adjust_position_quantity(asset_id: AssetId, new_quantity: float | int) → None[source]

Adjust position quantity directly (for corporate actions like stock splits).

This method sets the position quantity to a new value while keeping the cost_basis unchanged. This is appropriate for stock splits where the total investment value remains the same but the number of shares changes.

Updates both internal portfolio (for broker operations) and external portfolio (for strategy/reporting).

Parameters:

  • asset_id (NewType(AssetId, str)) Asset to adjust

  • new_quantity (Union[float, int]) New position quantity

Return type:

None

Example

>>> # 2:1 stock split: 100 shares @ $100 avg cost  200 shares @ $50 avg cost
>>> broker.adjust_position_quantity("AAPL", 200)
adjust_cash(amount: float) → None[source]

Adjust cash balance (for corporate actions like cash dividends).

This method adds or subtracts cash from the portfolio. Positive amounts add cash (e.g., dividend payments), negative amounts subtract cash (e.g., rights offering subscription).

Updates both internal portfolio (for broker operations) and external portfolio (for strategy/reporting).

Parameters:

amount (float) Amount to add (positive) or subtract (negative)

Return type:

None

Example

>>> # Dividend payment: 100 shares  $2.50/share = $250
>>> broker.adjust_cash(250.0)

can_fill(price: float | Decimal | None = None, high: float | Decimal | None = None, low: float | Decimal | None = None) → bool[source]

Check if order can be filled at given price or OHLC range.

For intrabar execution (matching VectorBT Pro): - Limit orders (TP): Check if high (for longs) or low (for shorts) reached limit - Stop orders (SL/TSL): Check if low (for longs) or high (for shorts) reached stop - Market orders: Always fill

Parameters:

  • price (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) Current market price (close) - for backward compatibility

  • high (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) Bars high price (for intrabar limit order checks)

  • low (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) Bars low price (for intrabar stop order checks)

Return type:

bool

Returns:

True if order can be filled

Note

If high/low are provided, uses intrabar execution logic. If only price is provided, falls back to end-of-bar logic.

class ml4t.backtest.execution.slippage.SpreadAwareSlippage(spread_factor: float = 0.5, fallback_slippage_pct: float = 0.001)[source]

Bases: SlippageModel

Slippage model that uses bid/ask spread from MarketEvent.

Fills at mid-price k spread, where k is a configurable factor (default 0.5). If bid/ask data is unavailable, falls back to PercentageSlippage.

Parameters:

  • spread_factor (float, default: 0.5) Fraction of spread to pay (default 0.5 = fill at mid)

  • fallback_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.001) Fallback percentage when spread unavailable (default 0.001)

Example

If bid=99.98, ask=100.02 (spread=0.04), mid=100.00: - Buy with k=0.5: Fill at 100.00 + 0.50.04/2 = 100.01 - Sell with k=0.5: Fill at 100.00 - 0.50.04/2 = 99.99

class ml4t.backtest.execution.slippage.VolumeAwareSlippage(base_slippage_pct: float = 0.0001, linear_impact_coeff: float = 0.01, sqrt_impact_coeff: float = 0.0, fallback_slippage_pct: float = 0.001, max_participation_rate: float = 0.1)[source]

Bases: SlippageModel

Slippage model that scales with order size relative to volume.

Calculates slippage as f(order_size / volume), where f can be: - Linear: impact = base + linear_coeff participation_rate - Square-root: impact = base + sqrt_coeff sqrt(participation_rate)

If volume data is unavailable, falls back to PercentageSlippage.

Parameters:

  • base_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.0001) Base slippage percentage (default 0.0001)

  • linear_impact_coeff (float, default: 0.01) Linear impact coefficient (default 0.01)

  • sqrt_impact_coeff (float, default: 0.0) Square-root impact coefficient (default 0.0)

  • fallback_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.001) Fallback when volume unavailable (default 0.001)

  • max_participation_rate (float, default: 0.1) Maximum participation rate (default 0.1 = 10%)

Example

Order size = 1000, Volume = 100000 (participation = 0.01 = 1%) Linear model: impact = 0.0001 + 0.01 0.01 = 0.0002 = 0.02%

__init__(base_slippage_pct: float = 0.0001, linear_impact_coeff: float = 0.01, sqrt_impact_coeff: float = 0.0, fallback_slippage_pct: float = 0.001, max_participation_rate: float = 0.1)[source]

class ml4t.backtest.execution.slippage.OrderTypeDependentSlippage(market_slippage_pct: float = 0.001, limit_slippage_pct: float = 0.0001, stop_slippage_pct: float = 0.0005, default_slippage_pct: float = 0.001)[source]

Bases: SlippageModel

Slippage model with different rates per order type.

Market orders pay more slippage (immediate execution, worse price). Limit orders pay less (patient, better price). Stop orders pay medium slippage (conditional execution).

Parameters:

  • market_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.001) Slippage for MARKET orders (default 0.001)

  • limit_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.0001) Slippage for LIMIT orders (default 0.0001)

  • stop_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.0005) Slippage for STOP/STOP_LIMIT orders (default 0.0005)

  • default_slippage_pct (float, default: 0.001) Slippage for other order types (default 0.001)

Example

Market order: 0.10% slippage (aggressive execution) Limit order: 0.01% slippage (patient execution) Stop order: 0.05% slippage (conditional execution)

class ml4t.backtest.execution.fill_simulator.FillSimulator(asset_registry: AssetRegistry, commission_model: CommissionModel | None = None, slippage_model: SlippageModel | None = None, market_impact_model: MarketImpactModel | None = None, liquidity_model: LiquidityModel | None = None, margin_account: MarginAccount | None = None, max_leverage: float = 1.0) → None[source]

Bases: object

Simulates order fills with realistic market constraints.

Responsibilities: - Determine if order can fill at market price - Apply market impact to market price - Calculate fill price with slippage - Apply liquidity constraints - Check margin requirements (derivatives) - Check cash constraints (equities) - Calculate commission and slippage costs - Update order state and model states - Generate FillEvent

This class does NOT: - Track positions (PositionTracker) - Route orders (OrderRouter) - Manage bracket orders (BracketOrderManager)

Design Notes: - Order mutation: FillSimulator calls order.update_fill() to update order state.

This is acceptable coupling because fills conceptually update order lifecycle.

  • Model updates: FillSimulator updates MarketImpactModel and LiquidityModel state after fills. This keeps all fill-related side effects in one place.

  • Stateless operation: Position and cash are passed as parameters to try_fill_order, not stored in FillSimulator. This allows testing without broker context.

Parameters:

  • asset_registry (AssetRegistry)

  • commission_model (CommissionModel | None, default: None)

  • slippage_model (SlippageModel | None, default: None)

  • market_impact_model (MarketImpactModel | None, default: None)

  • liquidity_model (LiquidityModel | None, default: None)

  • margin_account (MarginAccount | None, default: None)

  • max_leverage (float, default: 1.0)

__init__(asset_registry: AssetRegistry, commission_model: CommissionModel | None = None, slippage_model: SlippageModel | None = None, market_impact_model: MarketImpactModel | None = None, liquidity_model: LiquidityModel | None = None, margin_account: MarginAccount | None = None, max_leverage: float = 1.0) → None[source]

Initialize fill simulator.

Parameters:

  • asset_registry (AssetRegistry) Registry for asset specifications

  • commission_model (CommissionModel | None, default: None) Optional commission calculator

  • slippage_model (SlippageModel | None, default: None) Optional slippage calculator

  • market_impact_model (MarketImpactModel | None, default: None) Optional market impact model

  • liquidity_model (LiquidityModel | None, default: None) Optional liquidity constraint model

  • margin_account (MarginAccount | None, default: None) Optional margin account (for derivatives)

  • max_leverage (float, default: 1.0) Maximum leverage allowed (default 1.0 = no leverage). For cash-based trading, limits position size to max_leverage * available_cash. Example: max_leverage=2.0 allows positions up to 2x cash balance. This prevents unlimited leverage as capital depletes.

try_fill_order(order: Order, market_event: MarketEvent | None = None, *, current_cash: float = 0.0, current_position: float | int = 0.0, market_price: float | Decimal | None = None, timestamp: datetime | None = None, high: float | Decimal | None = None, low: float | Decimal | None = None, close: float | Decimal | None = None) → FillResult | None[source]

Attempt to fill an order using MarketEvent or legacy OHLC parameters.

This method applies all market realism constraints: 1. Validates order can fill at market price (using intrabar if high/low provided) 2. Applies market impact to market price 3. Calculates fill price with slippage 4. Applies liquidity constraints 5. Applies margin or cash constraints 6. Calculates commission and slippage costs 7. Updates order state 8. Updates model states (market impact, liquidity) 9. Generates FillEvent

Parameters:

  • order (Order) Order to attempt filling

  • market_event (MarketEvent | None, default: None) MarketEvent containing OHLCV and other market data (PREFERRED)

  • current_cash (float, default: 0.0) Available cash for purchases

  • current_position (Union[float, int], default: 0.0) Current position quantity for the asset

  • market_price (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) (DEPRECATED) Current market price - use market_event instead

  • timestamp (datetime | None, default: None) (DEPRECATED) Event timestamp - use market_event.timestamp instead

  • high (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) (DEPRECATED) Bars high price - use market_event.high instead

  • low (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) (DEPRECATED) Bars low price - use market_event.low instead

  • close (Union[float, Decimal, None], default: None) (DEPRECATED) Bars close price - use market_event.close instead

Return type:

FillResult | None

Returns:

FillResult if order was filled, None if order cannot be filled

Note

BACKWARD COMPATIBILITY: This method supports both old and new signatures:

NEW (recommended):

fill_simulator.try_fill_order(order, market_event, current_cash=, current_position=)

OLD (deprecated, will be removed in v0.6.0):

fill_simulator.try_fill_order(order, market_price=, high=, low=, close=)

Using legacy parameters will emit a deprecation warning.

This method has side effects: - Modifies order state via order.update_fill() - Updates market impact model state - Updates liquidity model state - Increments internal fill counter

For VectorBT Pro compatibility, prefer passing high/low/close for intrabar execution. If only market_price is provided, falls back to end-of-bar logic.

reset() → None[source]

Reset fill simulator state.

Return type:

None

class ml4t.backtest.execution.trade_tracker.TradeTracker(precision_manager: PrecisionManager | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

Efficient trade tracker that builds complete trade records from fills.

Uses FIFO (First-In-First-Out) matching to pair entries with exits. Designed for minimal overhead during backtest execution.

Performance characteristics: - O(1) fill processing - O(1) amortized trade completion - Minimal memory allocation (reuses structures) - Lazy DataFrame construction (only when requested)

Bracket Manager

Bracket and OCO order management for broker simulation.

This module provides bracket order lifecycle management extracted from SimulationBroker to follow the Single Responsibility Principle.

## VectorBT Compatibility - Base Price Calculation

CRITICAL: VectorBT calculates TP/SL/TSL levels from BASE PRICE (close before slippage), NOT from fill_price (execution price after slippage). This matches real-world behavior where stop levels are set relative to the market price, not the slippage-affected fill.

Example (from empirical testing - TASK-005): ``` Close at entry: $43,885.00 BASE PRICE Entry slippage: +0.02% Entry price: $43,893.78 (= $43,885 * 1.0002)

TP = 2.5%: TP level: $44,982.12 (= $43,885 * 1.025) Based on CLOSE, not entry_price Exit slippage: -0.02% TP exit price: $44,973.13 (= $44,982.12 * 0.9998) ```

Implementation: When creating BRACKET orders, store the base price in order metadata: ```python order = Order(

, order_type=OrderType.BRACKET, tp_pct=0.025, # 2.5% TP metadata={base_price: market_event.close}, # CRITICAL for accuracy

)

If base_price is not provided, BracketOrderManager will estimate it by reversing slippage from fill_price, but this may have rounding errors.

Market Impact Models

Market impact models for realistic price simulation.

Market impact differs from slippage in that it represents the actual change in market prices due to trading activity, affecting all subsequent orders.

Corporate Actions

Corporate actions handling for ml4t.backtest.

Corporate actions are events that affect the equity structure of a company, requiring adjustments to positions, prices, and orders. This module provides a comprehensive framework for handling:

  1. Dividends (cash dividends, special dividends)

  2. Stock splits and stock dividends

  3. Mergers and acquisitions (cash, stock, mixed)

  4. Spin-offs

  5. Symbol changes/reorganizations

  6. Rights offerings

All actions maintain point-in-time correctness and properly adjust positions, orders, and price histories.
